title: A Phase 2, Open-label Extension Study to Evaluate the Long-Term Safety, Clinical Activity, and Pharmacokinetics of ALN-TTRSC in Patients With Transthyretin (TTR) Cardiac Amyloidosis Who Have Previously Received ALN-TTRSC
description_brief: The purpose of this study was to evaluate the safety and clinical activity of long-term dosing with revusiran (ALN-TTRSC). Dosing has been discontinued; patients are being followed-up for safety.

adverseEventsModule.timeFrame: All AEs that occurred after the start of study drug administration on Day 0 (Baseline) up to 90 days post modified early termination visit (End of Study); Mean duration of collection was 16 months.
adverseEventsModule.description: The same event may appear as both an AE and a SAE. However, what is presented are distinct events. An event may be categorized as serious in one subject and as nonserious in another subject, or one subject may have experienced both a serious and nonserious event during the study

limitationsAndCaveats.description: Safety and efficacy data are difficult to interpret due to the limited numbers of patients completing the study.

drug: revusiran (ALN-TTRSC) — a GalNAc-conjugated short interfering RNA (siRNA) therapeutic that knocks down hepatic transthyretin (TTR) production
explanation_target: Reason: The described trial tests revusiran (ALN-TTRSC) in transthyretin (TTR) cardiac amyloidosis, not Alzheimer's disease. Revusiran is an RNAi therapeutic designed to reduce hepatic TTR production (a disease-targeted approach for ATTR amyloidosis), and its development was stopped after a mortality imbalance was observed in late-stage studies. citeturn0search6turn0search3

Act: Key extracted details — drug name: revusiran (ALN-TTRSC); drug type/mechanism: first-generation GalNAc‑conjugated siRNA (RNA interference) targeting TTR produced by the liver; indication studied: hereditary/senile TTR cardiac amyloidosis (cardiomyopathy); study status: dosing discontinued and patients followed for safety after observed mortality imbalance. citeturn0search3turn0search6turn0search0

Reflect: Classification decision — The four target categories requested are defined for Alzheimer’s-disease trials (biologic vs small molecule disease‑targeting, cognitive enhancer, or neuropsychiatric symptom improvement). Although revusiran is a disease‑targeted biologic by mechanism (an RNA therapeutic that reduces a pathogenic protein), it is not an Alzheimer’s therapy and therefore does not fit the taxonomy intended for Alzheimer’s clinical trials. Per instructions, I classify this trial as 'N/A'. citeturn0search3turn0search6

Web-search supporting sources (selected): PubMed/ENDEAVOUR report describing discontinuation and mortality imbalance; PMC full article summarizing revusiran mechanism and trial termination; review/nonclinical safety paper describing revusiran as a GalNAc‑siRNA. citeturn0search0turn0search6turn0search3
